Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Language and Identity among Ethnic Minorities

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
How do linguistic variables gain social meaning in everyday interaction? What role does language play in creating identity? Is there a way of speaking that uniquely identifies a group, and if so, what are the linguistic characteristics?

Under the direction of Dr. Gregory Guy, Carina Bauman will investigate the interaction of language and ethnic identity by investigating language use within an Asian American sorority to answer the question how do these young women from diverse ethnic backgrounds work to collaboratively define what it means to be "Asian American." Important discourse events will be recorded to determine how particular linguistic resources are used to construct identities and community membership. Interviews will be recorded at the beginning and at the end of the academic year, and specific linguistics variables, such as prosody, phonation type, quotatives, and rising intonation, will be analyzed to investigate if they reveal patterns associated with ethnic identity. Linguistic data will also be collected from two control groups: Asian-American students not involved in an Asian-American sorority and college students of various ethnic backgrounds.

Since Asian Americans have until recently been a relatively understudied group within sociolinguistics, this study has the potential to make an important contribution to our picture of language and ethnicity in the United States.

POR.DRECONTENT:
With the support of this award, Carina Bauman has completed her doctoral dissertation, entitled "Speaking of Sisterhood: Language and Identity in an Asian American Sorority". This dissertation explores the linguistic practices of an understudied, yet growing and important, ethnic minority group in the United States. The findings suggest that many young Asian Americans exhibit particular characteristics in their spoken English that form part of their ethnic identity. In an increasingly diverse society, a thorough understanding of differences—including linguistic differences—is crucial to promote acceptance and avoid misunderstandings.

 

During the award period, the researcher conducted ethnographic fieldwork with an Asian American sorority at a New Jersey university. As a participant observer, she took part in several sorority activities, including recruitment (Rush), fundraising, and chapter meetings. The researcher also conducted individual interviews with 19 sorority members. This research yielded highly privileged information, since sororities and fraternities are exclusive organizations that tend to be highly secretive about their internal practices and routines.

 

In addition, the researcher conducted individual interviews 12 other female students of various ethnicities at the university. Approximately 35 hours of speech were collected in total. Because linguistic research on Asian Americans is so sparse, this corpus represents a valuable contribution to existing linguistic data, and the researcher has plans to make these recordings available to others.

 

There were two main sociolinguistic findings: the first regards the pronunciation of /o/, aka the GOAT vowel. In many dialects of American English, this vowel is undergoing a process of fronting, such that “goat” starts to sound more like gewt and “home” starts to sound more like hewm, etc. However, the Asian American young women in this study were not participating in this change, and were even changing their pronunciation in the opposite direction. Thus, the pronunciation of this single vowel can index a speaker’s ethnic identity.

 

The second finding regards prosodic rhythm, which refers to the relative length of adjacent syllables in connected speech. English is typically described as a stress-timed language, with stressed syllables being much longer than unstressed syllables. Languages described as syllable-timed include Spanish and Chinese. In these languages, adjacent syllables are roughly equal in length, regardless of stress. The effect of this difference on L2 speakers of English and speakers of English ethnolects has been well documented. For example, it has been found that the prosodic rhythm of Hispanic English varieties is more syllable-timed than standard English, but not as syllable-timed as standard Spanish. The current project found a similar pattern for Asian American English speakers.

 

Together, these results begin to give us a picture of the distinct characteristics of English as spoken by Asian Americans. This is important because for most of their history, Asian Americans have been saddled with dueling stereotypes: “Model Minority” or “Forever Foreigner”. The first stereotype presumes that Asian Americans achieve success by completely assimilating to prevailing cultural norms.
